summary: This is an email chain from March 2008 discussing the status of the state and federal cases against Jeffrey Epstein. It details the terms of a proposed non-prosecution agreement, Epstein's attempts to evade its requirements (pleading to a registrable sex offense, serving jail time, paying restitution), and strategic legal issues like double jeopardy and the statute of limitations. It also mentions Epstein subpoenaing victims not named in the state indictment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central defendant in both state and federal cases related to solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors. The email details his legal maneuvers to avoid the terms of a proposed non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: State Case Trial Date Set

events.title: Email Discussion on Case Status
events.description: An email is sent detailing the status of the state and federal cases, Epstein's attempts to avoid the non-prosecution agreement terms, and his subpoenaing of victims.

events.title: Legal Strategy Discussion on Jeopardy
events.description: A follow-up email discusses when double jeopardy attaches under Florida law and the implications for dropping state charges.

keyFacts: The state indictment against Epstein involved two girls, one of whom was also in the federal indictment. It charged solicitation of adult prostitution, not a child exploitation offense, despite Florida law not allowing a defense based on the victim's misrepresentation of age.

A proposed non-prosecution agreement required Epstein to: 1) plead to a state offense requiring sex offender registration, 2) agree to an 18-month incarceration term, and 3) agree to pay restitution and damages to victims. After signing, Epstein tried to evade all three requirements.
Epstein was subpoenaing victims for depositions who were not included in the state indictment, which the email author suggests was an attempt to gather information about the federal investigation.
Before federal involvement, local police were told Epstein would plead to a misdemeanor with no jail time, which prompted the FBI to step in.
Epstein's defense counsel had continued the state case repeatedly on the basis that it could not be resolved until the federal case was resolved.
